questiontext.text: Random variable CC is normally distributed with mean μ=150\mu = 150 and standard deviation σ=20\sigma = 20. C=N(150,20)C = \text{N}(150,\,20) Evaluate P(C<160)P(C < 160).

generalfeedback.text:
First, draw a sketch. We can label the CC axis by adding integer multiples of 20 to 150. We know to shade toward the left because small values of CC satisfy the condition C<160C<160.


We are given a specific cc value as a boundary. (Remember, for random variables we use uppercase letters, but for specific values we use lowercase.) c=160c = 160 We calculate the zz value of the boundary. z=c−μσ=160−15020=0.5\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{c-\mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{160-150}{20} \\\\ &= 0.5 \end{aligned}

We have rephrased our problem into a standard normal probability problem, because P(C<160)=P(Z<0.5)P(C<160) ~=~ P(Z<0.5)

So, we just need to evaluate P(Z<0.5)P(Z<0.5). To do this, you just need a zz-table.

zz P(Z<z)P(Z<z)
0.48 0.6844
0.49 0.6879
0.5 0.6915
0.51 0.695
0.52 0.6985

Thus, we find our answer. P(C<160)=0.6915P(C<160) = 0.6915
